What is the method of the perfection of patience?
The bodhisattva deeply thinks:

'The consciousness spirits of sentient beings, due to delusion, block themselves, are arrogant and self-important, always wanting to surpass others, and the pleasures of official rank, country, and the six sense objects, they want to monopolize them.

If they see others having them, the foolish immediately become greedy and jealous. Greed and jealousy are within, while anger and hatred are without. They do not realize the cessation of giving, and their madness lasts, long dwelling in blindness and darkness.
Transmigrating through the five paths, being burned in the Tai Shan mountains, as hungry ghosts and animals, they accumulate suffering to an immeasurable degree.'
The bodhisattva sees this and immediately awakens, sighing with regret:

'Why do sentient beings have the misfortune of losing their country and breaking up their families, endangering their bodies and destroying their clans? They suffer in life and bear the guilt of the three paths after death. It is all because they are unable to be patient and kind, which causes this.'
The Bodhisattva, upon awakening, immediately vowed:
'I would rather endure the cruelty of boiling water and fire, the suffering of being ground and sliced, and never become angry or harm sentient beings.
Forbearance is the source of myriad blessings.'

After awakening, the Bodhisattva practiced kindness in life after life. When sentient beings scolded, beat, or robbed him of his wealth, wife, children, or country, or endangered his life, the Bodhisattva immediately used the blessings of the Buddha's power of forbearance to extinguish his anger and hatred, and with compassion and pity, he rescued and protected them. If they escaped danger, he rejoiced for them.

In the past, the Bodhisattva, seeing the world's defilement and corruption, with rulers and ministers lacking the Way, turning their backs on truth and embracing falsehood, finding it difficult to guide and transform them, therefore concealed his brilliance, hid his shadow, and dwelt in a charnel ground, practicing the conduct of forbearance.

In the charnel ground, there was a calf that always took its feces and urine as food and drink, sustaining its body and life, exposed to the elements, contemplating with utmost sincerity, its appearance ugly and dark, despised by all.
The people of the country, seeing it, told each other:
'There is a ghost in this land.
' Those who saw it all spat and scolded, throwing dirt and stones at it.
The Bodhisattva had not a hair's worth of anger, and with a compassionate heart, he felt pity and said:
'Alas! These people do not see the Buddha's scriptures and yet commit such evil deeds.
' He vowed:
'If I am to become a TathÄgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, I will surely deliver them.
' The Bodhisattva's practice of forbearance in accordance with the Dharma is like this.

He said:

The Heavenly Emperor Shakra, the Four Heavenly Kings, the earth spirits, and the sea dragons, hearing the cries of grief, believed in his words and were all disturbed.

[The Birth Story of the Brahmin Ká¹£ÄntivÄdin] (44) In the past, when the Bodhisattva was a Brahmin named Ká¹£ÄntivÄdin, he lived in the mountains and forests, contemplating under a tree, subsisting on fruits and spring water.
The inner defilements are completely eliminated, dwelling in emptiness and tranquility, widely illuminating the six supernormal powers, attaining omniscience.
The fragrance of wisdom pervades the eight directions, above and below, the buddhas of the ten directions, the pratyekabuddha path, and the noble assembly of arhats all praise it.

Åšakra, BrahmÄ, the four heavenly kings, sea dragons, earth spirits, morning and evening respectfully bow with palms joined, receive the teachings and follow the wind, protecting their countries, with timely wind and rain, abundant harvests of the five grains, poisons eliminated and calamities extinguished, rulers and ministers flourishing.
The king named Kali entered the mountains to hunt, chasing after deer, following their tracks passing in front of the bodhisattva. The king asked the practitioner:
The animal tracks pass through here, what are you doing?
The bodhisattva silently thought:
Sentient beings are agitated, only concerned with their own lives, fearing death and craving life, how is my mind any different?
If I were to tell the king, his cruelty and lack of kindness would be my fault as well;
if I were to say I did not see, I would be lying.
The Bodhisattva was ashamed and lowered his head without saying anything.
The king became angry and said:
You are a beggar who is about to die. I am now the king, the most honored in the country. Why do you not answer in a timely manner but pretend to lower your head?
The name of the country was Pulling Out Nails and Claws. The Bodhisattva was sorrowful, pulling out nails and claws, showing the king as if he did not see.
He said:
The animal tracks pass through here, but you say you don't see them. The king's power is absolute, can you not kill them?
The Bodhisattva said:
I listen to the king.
The king said:
Who are you?
He said:
I am a person of forbearance.
The king angrily drew his sword and cut off his right arm.
The Bodhisattva thought:
My aspiration is for the supreme path, without contention with the times. This king still draws his sword against me, how much more so the common people?
I vow that when I attain Buddhahood, I will first deliver him, not allowing the multitude to give rise to evil deeds because of him.
The king said:
For whom?
He said:
I am a person of forbearance.

He also cut off his left hand, asking once and cutting once. He cut off his feet, ears, and nose. The blood flowed like a spring, and the pain was immeasurable. Heaven and earth shook, and the sun became dim.
The Four Heavenly Kings suddenly all came together and said angrily in unison:
This king is cruel and difficult to match.
They said to the Daoist:
Do not defile your mind.
We will kill the king, his wife and children, and destroy the entire country to show our displeasure.
The Daoist replied:
What are you saying?
This calamity is due to my not following the Buddha's teachings and harming others in my past life. The retribution for doing evil is like a shadow following a form.
In the past, I sowed little, but now I reap much. If I follow your orders, the disaster will be like heaven and earth, and I will suffer retribution for countless kalpas. How could this be possible?
The common people saw the change and rushed to take the blame, all saying in unison:
'The Daoist abides here, benefiting the country with auspicious blessings, warding off disasters and ending epidemics;
Yet this extremely foolish king, not knowing right from wrong, not understanding what to discard and what to adopt, maliciously harms the Primordial Sage.
We only pray that the Sage will not hold us responsible for this to the Emperor above.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'The king, with the evil of being undeserving of blame, painfully inflicted it upon my body. My heart has pity for him, just as a loving mother grieves for her infant child;
What offense have the common people committed to resent him?
If there is any doubt, then take my severed arm and show it to me.'
The people then took it, and milk and blood flowed together.
He said:
'I have the grief of a loving mother, and now it is shown here.'
The people saw his great faith and none did not receive his transformation, they withdrew with joy.

The Bodhisattva had a younger brother who also saw the origin of the Way. He was in a different mountain, using his heavenly eye to see through, he saw the gods, ghosts, and dragons discussing the king's evil, none did not harbor anger.
Fearing that his elder brother would harm his virtuous mind, he used his spiritual powers to go to his elder brother.
He said:
'Is there any injury?'
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
You want to test my faith.
Take my severed hands, feet, ears, and nose and put them back where they belong, and then I will believe it.'
The younger brother reconnected them and they were restored. The elder brother said:
'My faith in universal kindness is now proven.'
The gods of heaven and earth all wept with joy, bowed their heads in praise, encouraged each other, advanced their lofty conduct, received the precepts, and withdrew.

Since then, the sun and moon lost their luster, the five planets were out of order, strange phenomena occurred one after another, droughts and famines caused the people to suffer and resent their king.

[The Birth Story of the Youth] (45) In the past, the Bodhisattva was born into a poor family. The poor family did not raise him, but wrapped him in a cloth and silently placed him on the four streets at night when no one was around, and sent a thousand coins with him on the road.

The country customarily regards this day as an auspicious day, and the people of the whole country gather, with the gentlemen and common people each enjoying their food and happiness according to their kind.
The brÄhman saw the performance and praised those who attended the gathering, saying:
'Praise to those who gather today!
There is a separate one, like pure white rice without admixture, with a fragrant and fresh scent.
If there are today sons and daughters born into a noble and virtuous family,
In the assembly, there was a householder who alone had no heir. Hearing this, he silently rejoiced and sent people in all directions to search for abandoned children. The messengers asked passersby:
'Have you seen anyone abandon a child?'
The passersby said:
'There is a single mother who took it.'
The messengers searched for it and found its location, saying:
'Our four surnames are wealthy but have no heir. If you offer your child, you can obtain many treasures.'
The mother said:
'Leave money to send the child, and you can ask for the price as you wish.'
The mother obtained what she desired.
She raised the child for several months, and then her wife became pregnant and said:
'Because I had no heir, I raised a child of another surname. Heaven has bestowed blessings on me. Now what should I do with the child?'
She wrapped it in a cloth and placed it in the water at night.
The family's sheep were milked daily, and the herder followed and saw the child. He sighed and said:
Why did Heaven drop its child here?
He took it home and raised it with sheep's milk.
The four castes found out and said:
Why did you steal the milk?
He replied:
I found Heaven's abandoned child and raised it with milk.
The four castes were disappointed and regretted.

They raised it for several months. The wife finally gave birth to a son. Evil thoughts arose again, and she did the same as before, wrapping him in a dirty cloth and placing him in a carriage track. The child's mind was on the Buddha, the Three Jewels, and he was kind to his parents.

In the morning, there were several hundred merchants with carriages passing by this way. The oxen stumbled and would not move forward. The merchants examined the reason and saw the child. They were surprised and said:
How did Heaven's child end up here?

He carried the child in his arms and put him in the carriage. The oxen moved like a flowing river. Twenty li ahead, next to a pavilion where the oxen rested, there was a single mother who said to the merchants:
Give me the child to help me in my old poverty.
So she was given the child.
The mother raised him for a few years. The four surnames heard about this again and felt pity, saying:
Are we being unrighteous and destroying the heavenly virtue?
Again, with many treasures, they invited the child back to the house. Sobbing and blaming themselves, they equally raised the two children.
After several years, seeing the child's extraordinary intelligence and versatility, evil thoughts arose again, saying:
His brilliance overflows, while my child is not. He will surely be abducted.
He wrapped the child in a robe and abandoned him in the mountains, placing him in the bamboo, determined to starve to death.
The child gave rise to compassionate thoughts, saying:
When I attain Buddhahood in the future, I will surely save all suffering.
The mountains were near a stream. The child used his strength to shake himself out of the bamboo and onto the ground, rolling to the side of the water.
Twenty li away from the water, there was a corpse-carrying pole. A man who was collecting firewood saw the child from afar and went to look at him, sighing:
Did the Celestial Thearch drop his son?
He took him back and raised him.

The four castes heard about it again and their resentment was as before. They invited him back with many precious things and wept with grief. He also taught them writing, mathematics, astronomy, and divination. He could master all the arts upon seeing them once. He was naturally kind and filial, and his words always guided and transformed. The people of the country praised him as a sage, and Confucian scholars gathered like clouds.

The father had evil thoughts and his nature was extremely wicked. Previously, there was a blacksmith seven li away from the city. He wanted to kill the child and wrote a decree to the blacksmith, saying:
In the past, I raised this child. After the child entered my house, epidemics occurred one after another, and wealth and livestock perished.
The chief diviner divined and said:
The child caused this disaster.
The decree arrived and he was extremely frightened, throwing him into the fire.
The false decree said to the child:
'I am now in my declining years and have a serious illness. You go to the smith's place and carefully count the money and treasures. This is your lifelong wealth.'
The son received the order and went. Inside the city gate, he saw his younger brother playing with his companions, popping walnuts. The younger brother said:
'Brother's arrival is my good fortune. Please break some for me.'
The older brother said:
'Father has ordered me to go on this errand.'
The younger brother said:
'I will go in his place.'ğŸ”½He took the letter to the smith's place.
The smith received the letter and threw the younger brother into the fire.
The father's heart was anxious and frightened. He sent a messenger to fetch the son. The messenger saw the older brother and said:
'What has happened to your younger brother?'
The older brother related the situation as it had happened.
When the older brother returned and reported it, the father sent a horse to chase after the son, but he had already been reduced to ashes.
The father threw himself down, called out to heaven, and became angry. He blocked his qi inside, which eventually developed into a serious illness.
He also gave rise to a poisonous thought, saying:
'Since I have no heir, why not use this son?
He must kill him.
The father had a mansion a thousand miles away from the country, and he sent this son, saying:
'He has squandered my wealth, you go and calculate it.
Now I am sending a letter to the mansion, sealed in a wax envelope, you quickly deliver it.
' The letter secretly ordered:
'When this son arrives, quickly tie a stone around his waist and drown him in a deep abyss.'
The son received the order, bowed, and rode lightly, half-way there.
On the road, there was a brahman who had a distant relationship with the father, and they always exchanged letters and visited each other.

The brahman had a daughter who was both virtuous and wise, deeply knowledgeable about auspicious and inauspicious omens, astronomy, and weather forecasting. The son went to the brahman's residence and said:
'My father's close friend, the brahman, is staying right here.'
He told his followers:
'Now I want to visit and pay my respects, is that possible?'
The followers said:
'Good!'
He then went to pay his respects.
The brahman was delighted and said:
'My brother's son has come.'

He then ordered the scholars, Confucian students, and elders from the four neighboring states to gather, and they entertained and enjoyed themselves, and he consulted them on various doubts, and they were all delighted, staying until late at night, each tired and sleepy.
The woman secretly observed the man and saw that he had a pouch tied around his waist with a sealed letter. She quietly untied it and took it back, read its contents, and sighed, saying:
'What a demon this is, harming my kind son to this extent!'
She tore up the letter and wrote another one, whose contents said:

'I am in my declining years, gravely ill and getting worse by the day. That brahmin is an old friend of mine. His daughter is both virtuous and intelligent. I have decided to make her my son's wife. I will provide plenty of treasures and silk, and the betrothal gifts will be excellent. The small ceremony will be followed by the large one. On the day of taking a wife, follow this edict.'
After finishing the letter, she opened the door and returned it.
The next morning, as they continued on their way, the brahmins and scholars all sighed in admiration.
The mansion received the letter and, following the order, fully prepared the rites and went to the brÄhman's house.
The brÄhman and his wife discussed:
As for the ceremony of marriage, it begins with choosing a virtuous person, asking about faults, and divining signs. If they are well-mannered and complete, then I agree.
Now, a man is present without arranging a betrothal gift, and he has come. How could he be disrespectful?
They then withdrew and rested, saying:
Men and women becoming a couple has been so since ancient times.
A virtuous man and a chaste woman are also difficult to encounter.
Thus they accepted the betrothal gifts and held the ceremony. The nine clans praised, saying:
This glory will be passed down through the generations.
After the ceremony of taking a wife was completed, the mansion sent a report. The four clans heard of it and became extremely ill with jealousy.
The son heard that his relatives were ill and choked with sobs, saying:
Life is difficult to preserve, and it is like an illusion, not true.

The Brahmin wanted to choose an auspicious day to send him back, but the Bodhisattva's internal pain did not follow his words. The family rushed back, ascended the hall, bowed their heads, and the wife again bowed twice, wept, took three steps forward and bowed again, and addressed him by name, saying, I am the wife of your son so-and-so. I was personally summoned to serve so-and-so. I will uphold the family line and serve my in-laws with utmost propriety.
I only wish that the great man will quickly recover, blessings will come, and you will forever enjoy an endless life, allowing me to express my feelings and attain the virtue of a filial wife.
The four castes became resentful inside and died.
The Bodhisattva buried him with compassion and grief, and the whole country praised his filial piety. After the funeral, he practiced and perfumed the ten directions.
The Buddha told the monks:
The young man was me.
The wife was Gautami.
The four castes were Devadatta.
The Bodhisattva's practice of patience is like this.
In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great king who always nurtured and protected sentient beings with the four types of equanimity. His fame reached far and near, and none did not praise him.
His uncle was also a king, ruling in a different country. He was greedy by nature and shameless, considering cruelty to be valor.
The Bodhisattva Forest sighed:
'The Bodhisattva embodies the benevolence and kindness of the two polarities.'
Out of jealousy, he falsely slandered and created discord, raising troops to try to take away the Bodhisattva's country.
The Bodhisattva's officials all said:
'It is better to be a humble person with the benevolence of heaven, than to be a noble person with the ferocity of a wolf.'
The people said:
'It is better to be an animal with the Way, than to be a people without the Way.'

Selecting and training warriors, they arrayed the troops and shook the banners. The king ascended the platform to observe the troops. His emotions were heavy, and tears flowed down his face, covering his neck, as he wept.

'With my single body, I have destroyed the lives of millions of people. The country is lost and difficult to regain, a human body is difficult to obtain. My escape will bring peace to the borders of the country. Who will have any trouble?'
The king and the queen mother both entrusted the country to him.

The uncle entered the country and used cruelty as his governance. He killed the loyal and righteous, promoted flattery and deceit, and his policies were harsh and the people suffered. They cried out in resentment, thinking of the former king like a filial son remembering his kind parents.

The king and the queen mother lived in the mountains and forests. There was an evil dragon in the sea who coveted the queen's radiant appearance. He transformed into a brahman, with his hands clasped in a begging gesture, sitting with his head lowered in quiet thought, appearing to be like a Daoist practitioner in a state of meditation.
The king saw him and was delighted, daily gathering fruits to offer to him.
The dragon, taking advantage of the king's absence, stole the queen away and took her back to his sea dwelling.
He passed through a path between two mountains, where there was a giant bird that spread its wings to block the path and fought with the dragon.
The dragon shook the thunder and struck the bird, causing it to fall on its right wing, and thus it was able to return to the sea.
The king, picking fruit and returning, did not see his queen, and was disappointed, saying:
I have violated my past actions, and the misfortune has reached me?
So he took up his bow and arrow and went through the mountains searching for his original queen.
He saw a flowing spring and followed it to its source, where he saw a giant macaque and was moved to grief. The king sadly said:
Why are you grieving again?
The macaque said:
I and my cousin were kings side by side, but my cousin, with his strong power, has taken away my troops. Alas, there is no one to appeal to.
Why have you, my son, come to this mountain pass?
The Bodhisattva replied:
My sorrow is the same as yours!
I have also lost my queen and do not know where she has gone.
The macaque said:
Help me in battle and regain my troops;
Search for your queen, and you will surely find her.
The king agreed, saying:
Yes, you may.

The next day, the monkey fought with his uncle. The king drew his bow and aimed his arrow, with his arms and legs stretched out. The uncle was terrified from afar, trembling and running away. The monkey king's troops retreated. He then told the troops:
The main queen of the human king is lost in this mountain. You should search for her.
The monkey troops went in different directions. They saw a bird with sick wings. The bird said:
What are you looking for?
They said:
The main queen of the human king is missing. We are searching for her.
The bird said:
She was stolen by a dragon!
I am powerless. She is now on a large island in the ocean.
After speaking, the bird died.
The monkey king led his troops, following the path to the ocean, worried about how to cross.
Shakra, the Lord of the Heaven, transformed into a sick and scabrous monkey, and came forward, saying:
'Now the multitude of workers is as numerous as the sands of the sea. Why worry that we will not reach the other continent?
Now each of us will carry stones to fill in the sea, which can become a high mountain. What is the use of just connecting the continent?

' The monkey king then appointed him as the supervisor. The multitude followed his plan, and the work of carrying stones was completed. The multitude was able to cross over and piled up the continent.
The dragon created poisonous mist, and the entire monkey multitude became ill and fell to the ground.
The two kings were dejected and worried. The young monkey said again:
'Order the multitude to recover from their illness, and do not trouble the sages to think about it.
' He then applied heavenly medicine to the noses of the multitude, and the multitude then shook their noses and their strength surpassed before.
The dragon then raised wind and clouds to block the sun in the sky, and the lightning shone brightly in the sea. It angrily thundered and shook the heavens and the earth.
The young monkey said:
'The human king's wonderful archery, the lightning is the dragon.
Shoot the arrow to remove the evil, and bring blessings to the people. The multitude of sages will have no resentment.
The lightning and thunder flashed, and the king shot an arrow that hit the dragon's chest. The dragon was shot dead, and the monkey hordes praised it.
The young monkey pulled out the dragon gate key, opened the gate, and brought out the queen. The heavenly ghosts were all delighted.
The two kings returned to their original mountains and apologized to each other, humbly shining and respectfully yielding.

When the king's brother-in-law died without an heir, the subjects rushed to search for the old king. They met the king and his ministers in the mountains, wept sorrowfully together, and returned. They also obtained the king's brother-in-law's country. The people rejoiced and praised him for ten thousand years. With a great amnesty and lenient governance, the people's hearts were filled with joy and smiles as they walked.
The king said:
My wife left for the heavens and stayed alone for one night. Many have doubts about this, let alone for ten days.
Return to your clan and follow the ancient rites.
The queen said:
Although I was in the den of filthy insects, I was like a lotus flower dwelling in muddy water.
My words are true, and the earth will split open.
As soon as he finished speaking, the earth split open, and he said:
My faith is now manifested.
The king said:
Excellent!
The practice of Å›ramaá¹‡as is indeed upright and pure.
From then on, in the country, merchants yielded profits, scholars declined positions, the powerful endured the lowly, and the strong did not oppress the weak. This was the king's transformation.

The adulterous woman changed her ways, guarded her chastity at the risk of her life, the deceitful valued trustworthiness, and the crafty guarded truthfulness. This was the transformation of the queen.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The king of that country at that time was none other than myself.
The queen was none other than GopÄ«.ğŸ”½The uncle was none other than Devadatta.
Åšakra, Lord of the Devas was none other than Maitreya.
The bodhisattva practices the perfection of patience like this.

(47) The Past Life of the Monkey (47) In the past, the Bodhisattva was a monkey. His strength was rare, and his wisdom surpassed that of humans. He always had universal compassion and saved sentient beings.

He lived in a deep mountain, climbed a tree to pick fruit, and saw a poor person in a mountain valley who was unable to get out. For several days, he wailed and called out to heaven, begging for help.
The monkey heard his cries and tears flowed from sorrow. He said:
'I vow to seek Buddhahood only for the sake of such beings.
If I do not save this person now, he will certainly die of starvation.
I will follow the shore and down the valley to carry him out.'
He then entered the deep valley, had the person carry him, climbed up the grass on the mountain, placed him on level ground, and showed him the path, saying:
'Go wherever you want to go. After you leave, be careful not to do evil.'
The person who was carried out was exhausted and lay down to rest.
The person said:
'The valley is in famine, and now leaving is the same, what difference is there?'
He thought in his mind:
'I should kill the monkey and eat it, to sustain my life.
Isn't that also acceptable?'

He struck the monkey's head with a stone, and blood flowed like vermilion on the ground. The monkey lay down, startled and got up, dizzy and clung to the tree. His mind was without any thought of anger, with compassion and pity, grieving over the evil in his heart, he thought to himself:
'Those whose strength I cannot save, I wish that in their future lives they will always encounter the Buddhas, believe and accept the teachings of the Way, practice them and attain liberation.
May they not have thoughts of evil like this person in life after life.'
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The monkey was me.
The man in the valley was Devadatta.
The practice of forbearance in the perfection of patience of the bodhisattva is like this.
[The Dragon's Past Life] (48) In the past, the Bodhisattva and Ä€nanda together finished their offenses and became dragons. One of the dragons said:
'Only you and I have seen everything in the ocean. How about going to the land together to play?'
He replied:
'People on land are evil, and encountering the extraordinary is unavoidable, so we cannot go out.'
A dragon said again:
'Transform into a small snake.
If there are no people on the road, follow the main road to play;
If you encounter people, then hide.
What is there to worry about?'
Then they agreed and went up to play together.
Not long after coming out of the water,
they encountered a venomous viper. The viper saw the two snakes and evil thoughts arose, intending to harm them, so it spat out poisonous foam at the two snakes.
One snake had the intention to kill the venomous viper with its spiritual power;
The other snake had a compassionate mind, endured and advised against it, saying:
'As a lofty person, one should forgive the foolishness of the masses. To endure what cannot be endured, this is the great precept of the Buddha's true teaching.'
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The one who is greedy and lustful, without any mind of benevolence and righteousness,
Jealousy and desire to harm the sage, only silent forbearance is peace.
Those who are not in accord with the Dharma, without a compassionate mind within,
Stingy and evil, harming giving, only silent forbearance is peace.
The one who is negligent and without precepts, cruel and harmful, harboring a mind of theft,
Not following and conforming to the Way and virtue, only silent forbearance is peace.
Turning one's back on kindness and lacking gratitude, falsely adorning and acting hypocritically,
This is the extreme of foolishness, only silent forbearance is peace.'
One snake then praised the virtue of forbearance, spoke the verses and presented the meaning. The other snake respectfully accepted and did not harm the other.
One snake said:
Can we return to the ocean?

They agreed and went together, displaying their majestic spiritual power, shaking the heavens and earth, causing clouds to rise and rain to fall, and the dragon's transformations dazzled. Humans and ghosts were all frightened, and the snake became terrified. The corpse watched without knowing, fasting for seven days.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
At that time, the one who wanted to harm the snake dragon was Ä€nanda.
The one who spoke of the Dharma of patience and the dragon was myself.
The poisonous snake was Devadatta.
The Bodhisattva, wherever he was born, practiced patience. Although he was in the animal realm, he did not forget his practice.
The Bodhisattva's practice of patience is like this.

[The Jataka of King Nanda] (49) In the past, there was a country named MathurÄ, and the king was named Nanda. He studied the divine scriptures and understood all the mysteries. He realized that the world is impermanent and said:
My body will decay and become fertilizer for the world. Which country can be kept?

Renouncing glory and pleasure, he donned the Dharma robes of a great being, with a single bowl of food as sustenance, and upheld the precepts of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, making the mountains and forests his home for thirty years.
Beside the tree was a pit, thirty zhang deep.
At that time, a hunter chasing a deer fell into the pit.
At that time, there was a bird and a snake, each startled and falling together, their bodies all injured, and they were also exhausted.
Looking up to the sky, they wailed with a voice of loneliness and poverty.
The Daoist was moved, and when he lit a fire to look, tears flowed down his face as he approached the pit and said,
'You should not worry, I will save you from this great danger.'
He then made a long rope and climbed up with it, and the three creatures, sometimes biting and sometimes holding on, eventually managed to save their lives.
Together they kowtowed and thanked him, saying:
'Our lives were like flickering candles, but thanks to the Daoist's benevolence and vast compassion, we have been able to see the sun again.
I wish to use this body to provide for the needs of the multitude, to repay a little of the great debt, even if it is not even a hundredth part.'
The Daoist said:

'I am the king of a country, with a large population and many treasures in the palace. My harem and court ladies are the best in all countries. Whatever I wish for is immediately granted. What is there that I cannot obtain?

I regard the country as a den of resentment, and the colors, sounds, fragrances, flavors, and luxurious garments as wrong thoughts. The six swords cut my body and the six arrows shoot my body. Because of these six wrongdoings, I revolve and receive suffering, with the three evil paths being extremely severe and difficult to endure. I am greatly disgusted by this.

I abandon the country to become a monk, wishing to attain the state of a Tathagata, one who is free from attachment, a Perfectly Enlightened One, a Master of the Dharma, a Teacher of Gods and Humans, to transform the multitude of beings and cause them to return to their original state. Is it only for the three of you alone?
Each return to your old residences to see your relatives, and cause them to take refuge in the Three Treasures without violating the Buddha's teachings.'
The hunters said:

'I have lived in the world for many years, and although I have seen Confucian scholars accumulate virtue and do good, how can there be disciples of the Buddha like you who forgive themselves and help others, hiding their virtues without proclaiming their names?
If there are Daoists like this, I wish you would come to my house to beg for a small offering.'
The crow said:
'My name is Pei. If there are difficulties for Daoists, I wish you would call my name and I will come running.
' The snake said:
'My name is Zhang. If Daoists have any troubles, I wish you would call my name and I will definitely come to repay your kindness.'
After saying farewell, they each withdrew.
'One day, the Daoist came to the hunter's house. The hunter saw him coming from afar and told his wife:
'That inauspicious person is coming. I order you to prepare a meal.'
He slowly set it out, but he did not eat until after noon.
His wife saw the Daoist and became angry. She delayed setting out the food and idly talked until after noon.
The Taoist priest retreated and returned to the mountain. Seeing a crow, he called out its name, saying:
Pat.
The crow asked:
Where have you come from?
He said:
I have come from the hunter.
The crow said:
Have you eaten?
He said:
He has not yet prepared it, and the day has passed noon. It is not the time to eat, so I have retreated.
The crow said:
A ghost of misfortune is difficult to save with kindness. Going against benevolence and turning one's back on kindness is the greatest evil.
I have no food or drink, so there is nothing to offer.
Stay here and sit, I will return soon.
It flew to the country of Panca, entered the king's harem, and saw the king's wife lying down. In her head ornaments was a bright pearl.
The crow carried it away and brought it back to offer to the Taoist priest.
When the wife woke up from her sleep and searched for it, she could not find it, so she immediately reported it to the king.
The king ordered the ministers and people:
'Whoever finds it will be rewarded with a thousand ounces of gold and silver, and a thousand head of cattle and horses;
Those who do not find it will be severely punished and their clans destroyed.'
The Daoist priest was reported by a hunter, and the hunter bound him and informed on him.
The king said:
'Where did you get this treasure?'
The Daoist priest deeply thought:
'If I tell the truth, the entire country's crows will die;
If I say I stole it, I am not a disciple of the Buddha.'
He silently endured the torture, with thousands of lashes, not resenting the king or blaming the other, and made a vow of great compassion:
'May I attain Buddhahood and deliver all sentient beings from suffering.'
The king said:
'Take the Daoist priest and bury him, leaving only his head exposed, and execute him tomorrow.'
The Daoist priest then called out to the snake:
'Chang.'
The snake said:
'No one in the world knows my name except the Daoist priest.'
There must be a reason for shouting and calling out to each other like this.
He quickly went and saw the Daoist in this state. He kowtowed and asked:
'How did this happen?'
The Daoist fully explained the reason.
The snake shed tears and said:
'The Daoist's kindness is like heaven and earth, yet he still encounters misfortune. How much more so for those without virtue? Who will bless them?
Heaven's kindness has no resentment. This king only has one prince and no other heir apparent. I will enter the palace, bite and kill the prince, and apply my divine medicine to him to heal him.'
The snake entered the palace at night, bit him, and he died immediately.
The corpse was kept for three days. The king decreed:
'Anyone who can revive the prince will be given half the country to rule.'
It was carried to the mountains and was about to be cremated.
As it passed by the Daoist's side, the Daoist said:
'What illness did the prince have that led to his death?
And yet he has not been buried yet!
I can revive him.'
The attendants heard this and rushed to report it to the king.
The king was both sad and happy, and lamented even more:
I forgive your crime and divide the country for you to be king.
The Daoist applied medicine to the prince's body, and the prince suddenly rose up and said:
Why am I here?
The attendants fully explained the reason.
The prince returned to the palace, and everyone rejoiced.
He divided the country and gave it to the prince, but the prince accepted none of it.
The king woke up and said:
He does not accept the divided country, so how could he steal?
He asked:
What country are you from?
What do you see as the reason for becoming a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Where did you obtain the pearl?
Your conduct is so lofty, yet you suddenly suffered this calamity. What will you do now?
The Daoist explained the details, and the king was moved to tears.
The king told the hunter:
You have made meritorious contributions to the country. Call all your nine relatives to come. I want to heavily reward them.
The relatives, both near and distant, all went to the palace gate. The king said:
'Unfilial and ungrateful, evil is the foremost.'
He had them all killed.
The Daoist entered the mountains to study the Dao, diligently and tirelessly, and upon his death, was reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The Daoist at that time was me.
The crow was ÅšÄriputra.
The snake was Ä€nanda, and the hunter
was Devadatta.
His wife was the daughter of the Hu family.
The bodhisattva's vast benevolence and perfection of forbearance is like this.

[The Birth Story of the Dragon King Bhandha] (50) Long ago, there was a king of the country of Kusinagara named Ika-datta. His country was vast, with a flourishing population. He ruled the country righteously, not oppressing the people.
The king had two children, a boy and a girl. The boy was named Sudatta and the girl was named Anjana. They practiced purity and the king cherished them greatly.

A golden pond was made for them and the two children entered the pond to bathe. In the pond there was a turtle named Jin, blind in one eye, also playing in the water, touching the bodies of the two children. The children were startled and cried out loudly!
The king then asked them the reason.
They said:
There is something in the pond that touches us and frightens us.
The king angrily said:
The pond was made for the children. What creature is dwelling there and scaring my children?
He ordered a net to be cast to catch it. A strange ghost dragon quickly caught it.
The fisherman caught the turtle. The king said:
How should it be killed?
The ministers said various things:
Cut off its head.
Some said:
Burn it alive.
Some said:
Chop it up and make soup.
A minister said:ğŸ”½It should be put in a cage and paraded through the streets, then released.
'This killing is not cruel, but throwing them into the great ocean is what is called cruel.'
The turtle laughed and said:
'This is indeed cruel.'
The king had them thrown into the river.
The turtle escaped and joyfully went to the dragon king, reporting:
'The human king Iká¹£vÄku has a daughter who is upright and radiant, a heavenly maiden to match.
The human king is now obsessed with her. Great king, you wish to form a matrimonial alliance with your daughter.'
The dragon said:
'Is it true?'
The turtle said:
'Indeed it is.'
For the turtle, they prepared sumptuous food in all precious vessels. The turtle said:
'Send a wise minister to follow them quickly. Our king wishes to obtain their decision.'
The dragon sent sixteen wise ministers who followed the turtle to the moat below the human king's city. The turtle said:
'You all stay here!
I will go up and report.'
The turtle then fled and never returned.
The sixteen ministers, anxious and worried, all entered the city to see the king. The king said:
'Why have the dragons come?
' They replied:
'The heavenly king is benevolent and gracious, he wants to give his precious daughter as a wife for us dragons, so he has sent us ministers to welcome her.
' The king angrily said:
'How can the daughter of a human king be a match for a snake dragon?
' The dragons replied:
'The great king has sent a divine turtle to proclaim the decree, we have not come in vain.
' The king did not agree.
The dragons transformed, causing all the objects in the palace to become dragons, shining and circling around the king in front and behind.
The king was frightened and cried out!
The ministers were startled and all went to the palace to ask the reason.
The king fully explained the situation, and the ministers all said:
'How can we lose the country for the sake of one woman?
' The king and the ministers went to the water to see the woman off, and she became the dragon queen's daughter-in-law, giving birth to two children, a boy and a girl.
The male is named Pan-da, and when the dragon king dies, the male succeeds to the throne as king.

He wished to abandon the defilements of worldly glory and study the aspiration for lofty conduct. His wife had tens of thousands of followers, but they still could not escape even if they fled to a secluded place.
He went ashore and hid under a pippala tree, transforming his body into a coiled snake.
At night, there were the lights of lamps, dozens of them under the tree. Day after day, various kinds of flowers rained down, their colors shining and fragrant, unlike anything seen in the world.
There was a man in the country who was able to despise dragons, named Pi-tu. He entered the mountains to seek the dragon and beg for alms. He saw a cowherd and asked if there was anything.
The boy said:

I saw a snake coiled up and lying under this tree. At night, there were dozens of lamp lights above the tree, shining brightly. The flowers were like snow, their colors shining and fragrant, difficult to describe. I leaned on it with my body, and there was no thought of harming it.
The magician said:
Excellent!
I have attained my wish.
He then smeared poison on the dragon's teeth, causing them to fall out, and beat it with a stick, breaking its skin and bones.

The magician stroked the dragon from head to tail with his hand, causing it immeasurable pain, but the dragon had no resentment in its heart. It blamed its own past actions for bringing this calamity upon itself and made a vow, saying:
May I attain Buddhahood and save all beings, bringing them all peace and security, just as I am now.
The magician took the dragon and put it in a small box, carrying it on his back as he went begging for alms.
Wherever he went, he would make the dragon dance, and the ministers and people of all countries were terrified of it.
The magician said:
I beg for a thousand catties of gold and silver each, a thousand male and female slaves each, a thousand elephants, horses, oxen, carts, and various animals each.
Wherever he went to each country, he obtained all of these.
He turned and entered the country of the dragon king's grandfather. His mother and the dragon brothers all searched on land, transforming into flying birds and hiding in the king's palace.
When the magician arrived, the dragon king transformed into a five-headed dragon, just about to dance, but when he saw his mother and siblings, he was ashamed and withdrew, no longer dancing.
The magician called him five or six times, and the dragon finally submitted.
His mother also transformed back into human form and met with the king, explaining the details.
The king and his ministers all felt pity. The king wanted to kill the magician, but the dragon pleaded with him, saying:
This is the result of karma I planted in the past, and I will now receive retribution. It is not appropriate to kill him and create more resentment in the future. I will give him whatever he seeks.
If you have such great compassion, you can attain the Way of the Buddha.
The king then used an example from another country, and gave him everything he desired.
The magician, having obtained this precious pearl, happily left the country. In another country, he encountered bandits, his body was cut to pieces, and all his wealth was taken away.
The dragon mother and her children took leave of the king:
'If the great king thinks of me and calls my name, I will come, and there will be no sorrow.'
The king, ministers, and people came to the shore to see them off. The entire country was in mourning, and none did not fall to the ground in grief.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The dragon king Varuna was myself.
The king of the country of Iká¹£uvÄku was Ä€nanda.
The mother was my mother now.
The younger brother was ÅšÄriputra.
The younger sister was the nun Utpalavará¹‡Ä.
The cruel man who killed the dragon was Devadatta.
The bodhisattva's vast compassion, reaching the other shore, practices patience like this.

In the past, the Bodhisattva was a sparrow king. With a compassionate mind, he saved all beings. He had even more compassion for his mother. He pitied their hardships with the same affection as for his own relatives. Seeing the multitude receive the Way, he rejoiced as if he himself were at ease. He loved and nurtured all beings as if protecting his own wounded body.
There was a tiger who ate beasts, and bones stuck in its teeth. It was sick and about to die.
The sparrow saw this and felt sorrowful, saying:
'The Buddhas say that food is a calamity, and this is indeed true.
' It pecked at the bones in its mouth, doing this every day.
The sparrow's mouth became wounded, and its body became emaciated. The bones came out and the tiger revived.
The sparrow flew up to a tree and spoke a Buddha's sutra, saying:
'Killing is cruel and violent, and its evil is no greater;
If it kills itself, how could it be pleased?
One should forgive oneself and measure others, and then there will be the benevolence of spring.
The benevolent are universally compassionate, and their blessings and rewards respond in kind;
Cruel and tyrannical, harming the masses, misfortune follows like a shadow.
Consider my words.
The tiger heard the sparrow's admonition and became enraged, saying:
You have just escaped from my mouth and yet dare to speak so much?
The sparrow saw that he was unteachable, felt pity for him, and quickly flew away.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The sparrow king was me.
The tiger was Devadatta.
The bodhisattva, life after life, with a compassionate mind saves the masses, taking it as his urgent task, yet still worrying about himself.
The bodhisattva's forbearance and giving in accordance with the Dharma is practiced like this.
The Sutra of the Naked Country (Fifty-Two) The Sutra of the Naked Country In the past, the bodhisattva, two cousins, each bringing their country's wealth, went together to the land of the naked.
The uncle said:
Those with abundant blessings have food and clothing naturally, while those with meager blessings rely on their muscles and strength.
Now, that naked land has no Buddha, no Dharma, and no assembly of monks. It can truly be called a land without people. Yet we are going there, looking up and down for their ideas. Isn't it difficult?

Entering the country and following the customs, advancing and retreating according to the etiquette, with a gentle mind and humble words, concealing one's brilliance and extolling one's foolishness, is the thought of a great person.
The elder said:
The rites cannot be violated, and virtue cannot be retreated. How can we go naked and destroy our old etiquette?
The younger one said:
The former sages' shadow is to sacrifice one's body but not one's practice. This is the constant precept.
Wearing gold inside and copper outside, changing the appearance to follow the times, first criticized and later praised, the great way of expediency!
So they went there together.
The elder said:
You enter first now, observe their gains and losses, and send a messenger to report the truth.
The younger one said:
I respectfully agree.
After ten days, the messenger returned and reported to the elder, saying:
You must follow the local customs.
The elder brother was furious and said:
How can a gentleman follow a man from an animal?
The younger brother did it, but I would not!

The custom of that country was to always have a feast on the night of the fifteenth day of the month. They would smear their heads with sesame oil, paint their bodies with white clay, wear necklaces of miscellaneous bones, strike two stones together, and men and women would hold hands, strolling and dancing.
The Bodhisattva followed them, and the people of the country marveled and praised him.
The king loved the people and respected the guests, and the king bought them all at ten times the price.
The elder brother entered the country in a carriage and said that he would strictly enforce the law, but the people immediately disobeyed.
The king was angry at the people's arrogance and took away their wealth, beating them with a whip.
The younger brother pleaded and they were released, and they all returned to their original country.
Those who sent off the younger brother were beaten along the way, and those who scolded the elder brother filled his ears.
The elder brother was ashamed and angry and said:
What relation does he have with you?
What enmity do I have with him?
You are being kind to him and taking away from me, aren't you just slandering me?
He tied up the younger brother and said:
'From now on, generation after generation, we will be bitter enemies, never forgiving each other.'
The Bodhisattva was moved to tears and vowed:

'May I in life after life encounter the Buddha, see the Dharma, and personally serve the Å›ramaá¹‡as. May the four kinds of kindness universally cover and benefit all beings. I will serve my elder brother as if he were myself. I will not go against this vow!'
From then on, the elder brother would always oppress the younger, but the younger brother would always save him.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The younger brother at that time is myself.
The elder brother is Devadatta.
The Bodhisattva's practice of patience through kindness and gentleness is like this.

The Sutra on Completing the Punishment of Starving for Six Years, [the Jataka of the King of a Country] (53) The Sutra on Completing the Punishment of Starving for Six Years, In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great king of a country. He took refuge in the Three Jewels and fully practiced the ten wholesome deeds. His virtue extended far and wide, and everyone followed his teachings. There was no need for weapons, and no prisons. The weather was timely, the country was prosperous, and the people were wealthy. The four borders were peaceful and secure, and there were no complaints on the roads. Even small children in the country talked about the six perfections and the true teachings, and no one did not recite them.
At that time, there was a brahman who upheld pure conduct, lived in seclusion in the mountains and forests, did not engage in worldly affairs, and only focused on virtue.

At night, he went to drink water and mistakenly drank from a lotus pond that had been planted by the people of the country. After drinking, he realized, 'They bought this pond to offer the flowers to the Buddha's temple, and the fruits are for their own use.
I drank the water without informing the owner, which is theft.
The harm of stealing first leads to entering Mount Tai, next to becoming an animal, being slaughtered and sold in the market to repay past debts.
If one obtains a human body, one will be a slave or servant.
I would rather finish it now and not leave future troubles.
He went to the palace and announced that he had committed theft, and only wished that the great king would punish him according to the law, finish it now and not seek faults later.
The king said:
'This is naturally occurring water, not a precious thing, so what crime is there?'
He replied:
'When buying a house, one already has the well; when occupying a field, one cherishes the grass. When drawing water from the well or cutting grass, one does not take it without notice.
I drank without notice, how is that not stealing?
I wish the king would judge it.'
The king said:
'State affairs are many, so sit in the garden for now.'
The prince ordered him to sit deep in the garden, and due to the king's many affairs he forgot about him for six days.
Suddenly he realized:
'Why is the Brahmin still here?
Quickly call him in.'

The Brahmin, who had been fasting and thirsty for six days, stood before the king. His body was emaciated and scarred. As he rose, he stumbled and fell to the ground. The king wept upon seeing him, saying:
'My transgression is grave.'
The queen laughed at him.
The king sent someone to bathe the Brahmin, prepared a feast, and himself made offerings, bowing his head in repentance, saying:
'When the people are hungry, I myself go hungry. When they are cold, I wear single clothes. How much more so for those who uphold the Way and bestow virtue!

The blessings of all the virtuous people in the country are not as good as the virtue of a single wise person of high conduct. The country is at peace, the people are secure, the four seasons are in harmony, and the grains are abundant. If not for the virtue of the precepts, who could have brought this about?'
He said to the Wayfarer:
'The crime of drinking water without informing is like this. How much more serious would the grave fault be for truly stealing?
With this pardon for your son, there will certainly be no future trouble.'
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
Very good!
I accept the king's generosity.

From then on, he transmigrated through birth and death without end. When he was about to attain Buddhahood, he did not eat for six years, and after his sins were exhausted and he attained the Way, he was freed by YaÅ›odharÄ, and RÄhula was born.
When the prince abandoned the country and diligently practiced in the mountains and forests, those with wrong views all said he was crazy, and slanderous voices were not one.

When the prince heard this, he endured this humiliation and slander, and in turn used compassion to save them. His blessings and virtues were fulfilled, and the Way was accomplished. The devas gathered like clouds, bowed their heads, and followed the wind. The emperors, ministers, and people all took refuge.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The king at that time is none other than myself.
The wife is YaÅ›odharÄ.
The prince is RÄhula.
The pursuit of evil brings misfortune, while the bestowal of virtue brings blessings. This should not be neglected!

The king forgot the Daoist's order and starved him for six days, and suffered the punishment of a six-year famine. After six days, because the king made offerings to him, his six-year calamity ended and he attained the Dao.
YaÅ›odharÄ laughed at him, and now she has the heavy illness of conceiving RÄhula for six years.
Because the brÄhmaá¹‡a deeply attached to the garden, the prince stayed in the dark for six years.

Foolish people are heavily deluded and do not understand right and wrong. Those who have evil intentions towards the Buddha, Å›ramaá¹‡as, and brÄhmaá¹‡as, and cut off their hands and pull out their tongues, suffer this pain in one lifetime;

Falsely beating with hands, falsely slandering with mouth, after death they enter Mount Tai. The ghosts of Mount Tai pull out their tongues and place them in hot sand, plowing them with oxen. They also nail their five limbs with burning nails, seeking death but not able to die.
Misfortunes and evils are like this. Upholding the right path without deviating.
The bodhisattva's practice of forbearance is like this.
